awd_titl_txt: Conference: Transdisciplinary coordination Workshop: building bridges for the next steps in knowledge co-production
awd_abstract_narration:
This project supports a workshop focused on transdisciplinary (TD) research. Transdisciplinary research transcends disciplinary boundaries, involving nonacademic social actors with academics from various disciplines to co-produce knowledge and solutions for urgent and complex issues. Exploring alternative ways of doing science, like transdisciplinary approaches, also implies exploring alternative ways of funding and supporting science-building and collaboration. The workshop aims to bring together institutions currently working to develop coordination activities in TD. Participants will identify possible pathways to the improved effectiveness of TD funding schemes, scoping of calls, proposal writing, and project implementation and assessment. The anticipated outcomes of the workshop are: 1) Stakeholder map and analysis of institutions working on training and funding of TD research projects globally; 2) List of coordination activities needed during the different phases of a transdisciplinary funding call; and 3) List of possible training and networking processes to be developed to make possible or enhance such coordination activities. The workshop will serve as a starting point to develop a support system for the coordination of transdisciplinary projects, offering tools, capacity building, financial resources and time for researchers and stakeholders involved in TD to develop their skills. The activities that will follow the workshop will increase the likelihood that the evidence generated by the projects will be used by diverse actors to improve the decision-making process to mitigate the impacts of Global Environmental Change.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Transdisciplinary Coordination Workshop, organized by the Inter-American Institute for Global Change Research (IAI) in partnership with the Belmont Forum, Global Development Network (GDN), and Inclusive Innovation, focused on addressing the growing need for transdisciplinary (TD) coordination to enhance research impact and foster effective collaborations. 

  

Strategic Achievements and Intellectual Contributions 

 

1. Advancing Transdisciplinary Coordination Practices 

 

TD research is fundamental in tackling climate change, biodiversity loss, and environmental degradation. The workshop highlighted best practices to improve TD coordination in funding schemes, proposal writing, project implementation, and research assessment. Through collaborative discussions, participants outlined three core clusters of coordination activities: 

  • Science Culture Shift: Transforming research norms to emphasize cooperative, solution-oriented science. 

  • Transforming Research Incentives: Enhancing funding structures to support TD projects. 

  • Capacity Surprising: Strengthening skills for interdisciplinary and intersectoral collaboration. 

 

Participants emphasized the importance of knowledge co-production involving diverse academic disciplines and non-academic stakeholders to generate actionable research. 

 

2. Strengthening Intersectoral Engagement 

Recognizing the gap between science and policy, the workshop focused on strategies to plan and implement TD research across the academic and implementation fields to ensure science is solution-oriented.  

Key results included: 

  • Stakeholder mapping to identify global actors involved in TD research. 

  • Development of a TD coordination framework to promote intersectoral collaboration. 

  • Engagement strategies to bridge the divide between academia and other sectors. 

 

The workshop underscored science-government-society interactions as key to TD research. 

3. Addressing Training Needs 

The workshop participants identified existing gaps in TD skills and tailored learning to address these gaps. Some key outcomes included: 

  • Expansion of TD training programs: Strengthening knowledge transfer among research institutions. 

  • Identification of resources: Improving access to knowledge for researchers, policymakers, and funding agencies. 

  • Strengthened institutional partnerships: Enhancing cooperation across actors in the Americas and global actors. 

 

The workshop particularly emphasized inclusive participation and supporting early-career scholars. 

4. Leadership in Science Diplomacy 

The discussions positioned TD coordination as a key enabler of international research collaboration. The workshop highlighted the potential contributions of TD to supporting global research funding calls such as Belmont Forum Collaborative Research Actions (CRA) and enhancing multilateral science-policy frameworks. 

Broader Impacts and Societal Relevance 

The workshop addressed the systemic barriers to knowledge production and underscored the importance of alternative funding models, ethical research practices, and TD training. The outcomes will support research teams in co-designing solutions with local communities, ensuring science-driven decision-making is both equitable and impactful. 

Key recommendations included: 

  • Developing open-access TD training platforms. 

  • Creating multilingual outreach materials to expand knowledge-sharing beyond English-dominant networks. 

  • Strengthening TD networking efforts to foster regional and international collaborations. 

 

Future Implementation 

Looking ahead, IAI and its partners plan to implement the workshop’s recommendations through: 

  • Strengthening trainings and resources related to science diplomacy to provide training and advisory services that support TD coordination broadly. 

  • Developing TD coordination guidelines to enhance project management and transparency.  

  • Developing a monitoring, learning and evaluation framework to assess research impact. 

 

By integrating TD coordination practices into funding, research design, and implementation, the workshop set a precedent for fostering transformative knowledge co-production. 

The success of this initiative underscores the importance of advancing transdisciplinary coordination. By strengthening regional and global TD networks, future research will contribute to more equitable and effective science-policy collaboration, ultimately driving solutions to the world’s most pressing environmental challenges.
